characters: COMPANY,' WRITTEN AND DIRECTED BY EDWARD D. WOOD, JR."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We move through a spooky shrouded parlor, as a storm rage outside.  THUNDER roars, and lightning flashes in the gia windows.  in the center of the room lies an oak coffin. Suddenly the lid starts to creak open. A hand crawls past the edge... and then the lid slams up!  Famed psychic CRI pops out.  Criswell, 40, peers at us intently, his gleami eyes framed under his striking pale blonde hair.  He into with absolute conviction:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Greetings, my friend.  You are interested in the unknown, the mysterious, the unexplainable... that is why you are here. So now, for the first time, we are bringing you the full story of what happened... (extremely serious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are giving you all the evidence, based only on the secret testimony of the miserable souls who survived this terrifying ordeal.  The incidents, the places, my friend, we cannot keep this a secret any longer. Can your hearts stand the shocking facts of the true story of Edward D. Wood, Junior??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lightning CRACKS. We drift down past the dark clouds... through the torrent rain... and end up...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've landed in Hollywood, 1952.  We're outside a teeny, playhouse.  The cracked marquee proclaims "'THE CASUAL

dialogues.speaker: COMPANY,' WRITTEN AND DIRECTED BY EDWARD D. WOOD, JR."
dialogues.text: Pacing nervously in the rain is ED WOOD, 30, our hero. Larger-than-life charismatic, confident, Errol Flynn-styl handsome, Ed is a human magnet.  He's a classically flawe optimist: Sweet and well-intentioned, yet doomed by his d within. The doors open, and Ed's pal JOHN "BUNNY" BRECKINRIDGE, 4 hurries out.  Bunny is a wealthy, theatrical fop wearing string of pearls.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Suddenly the rest of the cast runs up, frantically upset. flowing white dress is DOLORES FULLER, 23, a sharp, hungr for-a-career ingenue.  She's near tears.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, my dove just flew out the window!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She goes on in two minutes! What are we gonna do?? They all look to Ed, awaiting a response.  He thinks a se then excitedly CLAPS his hands.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores, give me your shoes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The ghost can be barefoot.  Give me your shoes! She hands Ed her white shoes.  He snatches one, grabs a p scissors, and starts CUTTING up the shoe.  Everyone is ba He keeps cutting the shoe... and it slowly takes on the s of a dove! Ed then grabs some pipe cleaners, works them into a shape sprints into the dressing room.  He takes some green eye and excitedly smears it on the pipe cleaners.  Ed then hu back out, jams the green pipe cleaners into the cut-up sh and it looks like a dove with an olive branch in its mout The cast is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow.

dialogues.speaker: BACK ONSTAGE
dialogues.text: The soldiers suddenly look up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, I think I see something! Dolores floats down onto the stage, holding out the dove.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I offer you mortals the bird of peace, so that you may change your ways and end all this destruction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and his gang celebrate opening night in a dirty 24-hou diner.  They're noisily slugging down drinks, in a big re booth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a show!  Everyone was terrific! Paul, your second-act monologue actually gave me chills, He grins at Actor #1, aka PAUL MARCO, a young eager beave who's loyal like a dog.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw thanks, Eddie. Actor #2, aka CONRAD BROOKS, a friendly, simple-minded lu runs up waving a newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got the early edition!  It was just dropped off at the newsstand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he smiles at everyone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is the big moment...! Ed opens the paper to the entertainment page.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INSERT - THE NEWSPAPER.  Ed turns to a column, "The Theat Life, By Victor Crowley."  Under this is a photograph of man with an ascot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody excitedly crowds around and starts reading.   A moment... and then their faces drop.  Clearly, this is a disastrous review.  Their faces get sadder, and sadder... then they finish.  A melancholy beat, until --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does that old queen know?  He wasn't even there! (he knocks back a drink)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sending a copy boy to do his dirty work.  Well fuck him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I really have a face like a horse?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does "ostentatious" mean? Ed calmly waves his arms for attention.  He tries to smil

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey.  Hey, it's not that bad.  You just can't concentrate on the negative.  He's got some nice things to say... (he scans the review)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, "The soldier costumes are very realistic."  That's positive! Everyone kind of stares at their drinks, depressed.  Ed launches into an upbeat speech.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hell, I've seen a lot worse reviews. I've seen ones where they didn't even like the costumes!  Like, that last "Francis the Mule" picture -- it got terrible notices.  But it was a huge hit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lines around the block.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So don't take it too seriously. We're all doin' great work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You really think so?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Absolutely!  It's just the beginning. I promise this: If we stick together, one day I'll make every single one of you famous. He smiles at everyone at the table.  They all believe wha says, and there is a hushed moment of dream-filled hope.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Dolores lie in bed, in the dark.  He stares vulner at her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Honey, what if I'm wrong?  What if I just don't have it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, it was only one review.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Orson Welles was 26 when he made "Citizen Kane."  I'm already 30!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, you're still young.  This is the part of your life when you're supposed to be struggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know... But sometimes I get scared this is as good as it's gonna get... Dolores kisses Ed affectionately.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Things'll change for us.  Nobody stays on the fringe forever. She gets out of bed.  We see her tiny apartment is drab a crumbling.  Dolores turns on the shower, then walks to th closet.  She looks inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: God, where's my pink sweater?  I can never find my clothes anymore...

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: He rolls over in bed, away from her.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU on Ed reading "The Hollywood Reporter."  A RUDE BOSS i suspenders suddenly strides up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey big shot, get off your ass.  They need a potted palm over in the Carl Laemmle Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure thing, Mr. Kravitz. Ed jumps up.  We WIDEN, revealing he's in a giant greenho packed with rows of potted plants and shrubs.  Ed grabs a palm tree and hurries out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed strolls across the busy movie lot, lugging the palm. passes a soundstage and notices the stage door open a cra Ed glances around, then puts down the palm and hurries in INT. SOUNDSTAGE Гі SAME TIME A big-budget foreign legion movie is shooting, with a hug and crew. A giant desert set has been erected, with camel real sand dunes. Ed is blown away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whoa, look at all this sand.  This is real sand!  My God, where'd they get all this sand?! A SECURITY GUARD sees him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, YOU.  This is a closed set. Ed is caught.  He hurries out. EXT. MOVIE STUDIO Гі DAY Ed continues across the lot, carrying his palm tree.  An CRUSTY MAN sticks his head out an office window.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, Eddie!  Come in here.  I got some great new stuff to show you. Ed puts down the plant again and runs in. INT. EDITING ROOMS Гі DAY The old guy is proudly showing Ed STOCK FOOTAGE on a movi The footage is totally random: Giant explosions, buffalos stampeding, tanks, an octopus swimming, etc. Ed is dazzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is fantastic!  What are you gonna do with it all?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, probably file it away and never see it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's such a waste.  If I had half a chance, I could make an entire movie out of this stock footage! (getting inspired)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, the story opens with these mysterious explosions.  Nobody knows what's causing them, but it's upsetting all the buffalo.  So the military is called in to solve the mystery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ya forgot the octopus.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I'm saving that for the big underwater climax! The old guy cackles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed finally carries the tree into the Laemmle Building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Young SECRETARIES in June Cleaver hairdos are giggling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say he was a girl trapped in a man's body.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll bet it hurt when they snipped his thing off. EEWWW!  All the girls shriek in horror.  Ed walks in and down his plant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you ladies gabbin' about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know that Christine Jorgensen freak?  He/she/it's in "Variety." Some producer is making a biopic.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (startled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: R-really?  I didn't see the story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, it was buried in the back.  The guy's a real smallГіtime operator. She holds up her "Variety."  Ed hurriedly takes it.

dialogues.speaker: VARIETY
dialogues.text: The story headline says "BOYГіTOГіCHICK FLICK TO CLICK." OUT, revealing we're now in

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed holds the newspaper while he paces around his apartmen The place has threadbare carpet, faded wallpaper, and an electric burner for a kitchen.  A handful of mangy DOGS r around. Tacked-up are movie posters for "DRACULA," "FREAK and "THE MAGNIFICENT AMBERSONS." Dolores talks on the phone, while Ed silently coaches her DOLORES (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I've got Mr. Edward Wood on the line.  Could you please hold? Ed gives her a thumbs up -- perfect!  He confidently take phone. ED (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, Mr. Weiss?  I heard about your new project and was curious if you signed a director.  Oh -- you haven't?  Well, if we could get together, I could explain why I'm more qualified to direct this than anyone else in town.  (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, I'd rather not go into it over the phone...  Alright.  Great!  l'll see you then!     Ed hangs up and YELPS excitedly.  He kisses Dolores.  She away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, I don't understand.  Why are you the most qualified director for the Christine Jorgensen Story?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nervous, he lies)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aw, er, it's just a bunch of hot air. I had to say something to get in the door.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed walks jauntily along, wearing a snappy suit.  He reach door that says "SCREEN CLASSICS Гі George Weiss, Presiden fixes his hair, checks his clothes, then enters. INT. SCREEN CLASSICS Гі SAME TIME It's a crowded root, piled with paperwork and files.  Fil are stacked everywhere, and framed oneГіsheets for "TEST BABIES," "BLONDE PICKUP" and "GIRL GANG" litter the crack walls.  Sitting behind the messy desk is GEORGIE WEISS, 6 rug merchant turned exploitation film producer.  He juggl large sandwich and angrily barks into the phone. GEORGIE (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, when I said you could have the western territories, I didn't mean all eleven states!  I meant California, Oregon, and uh, what's that one above it... Washington.  Oh really?!  Well screw you! Georgie slams down the phone.  He smiles warmly at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I help you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm Ed Wood.  I'm here about directing the Christine Jorgensen picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, well a couple of things have changed.  It ain't gonna be the Christine Jorgensen story no more. Goddamn "Variety" printed the story before I had the rights, and now that bitch is asking for the sky.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disappointed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're not gonna make the movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, of COURSE I'm gonna make the movie!  I've already preГіsold Alabama and Oklahoma.  Those repressed Okies really go for that twisted pervert stuff.  So we'll just make it without that she-male.  We'll fictitionalize it. Georgie bites into his sandwich.  Ed is dazed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there a script?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck no!  But there's a poster. Georgie pulls out artwork of a hermaphrodite: Man on the side, woman on the right.  The lettering screams, "I CHAN

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It opens in nine weeks in Tulsa.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (mustering up his courage)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Weiss, I'm your guy.  I work fast, and I'm a deal: I write AND direct.  And I'm good.  I just did a play in Hollywood, and Victor Crowley praised its realism.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm.  There's five-hundred guys in town who can tell me the same thing. You said on the phone you had some kind of "special qualifications." Ed takes a measured piuse.  This is his big revelation.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Weiss, I've never told anyone what I'm about to tell you... but I really want this job. (he gulps)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like to dress in women's clothing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you a fruit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, no, not at all!  I love women. Wearing their clothes makes me feel closer to them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So you're not a fruit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, I'm all man.  I even fought in WW2. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Course, I was wearing ladies' undergarments under my uniform.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You gotta be kiddin' me.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Confidentially, I even paratrooped wearing a brassiere and panties. I'll tell ya, I wasn't scared of being killed, but I was terrified of getting wounded, and having the medics discover my secret. Georgie sits back.  It's a hell of a story.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And this is why you think you're the most qualified to make my movie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  I know what it's like to live with a secret, and worry about what people are gonna think of you... My girlfriend still doesn't know why her sweaters are always stretched out. Georgie shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, you seem like a nice kid, but look around you... (he gestures at the posters)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't hire directors with burning desires to tell their stories. I make movies like "Chained Girls." I need someone with experience who can shoot a film in four days that'll make me a profit. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.  That's all that matters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: INT. BAR Гі DAY Ed sits morosely in a scuzzy bar, three empty shot glasse front of him.  A BARTENDER ambles over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you gonna get something else? Ed glumly empties his pocket.  All he has is change.  Ed and staggers out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed shuffles down the street, his head hanging low.  A restaurant door opens, and an EISENHOWER ERA NUCLEAR FAMI exits.  Whitebread Dad, Mom, Son, and Daughter stride out their starched clean clothes. They march obliviously past Ed.  He watches them go, then continues.  Ed reaches a building, "HOLLYWOOD MORTUARY," glances in the window.  A pause, then he does a doubletak

dialogues.speaker: THROUGH THE WINDOW
dialogues.text: The showroom is filled with sample coffins.  Lying inside is BELA LUGOSI.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: He is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lugosi slowly sits up inside the coffin.  Bela is an aged year-old man, once a great star, now a faded memory tryin hang on to his nobility.  Quite frail and tired, he is st master of the grand gesture. An UNCTUOUS SALESMAN steps up.  Bela speaks, in a thick Hungarian ACCENT which gives him an Old World elegance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Too constrictive.  This is the most uncomfortable coffin I have ever been in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, Mr. Lugosi, I've never had any complaints before.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The selection is quite shoddy.  You are wasting my time. Mildly annoyed, Bela climbs out. He straightens his cloak walks to the exit -- where be bumps into nervous Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, Mr. Lugosi??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you, I don't want any of your goddamn coffins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  I don't work here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh? Bela peers at Ed, then glances confusedly over his should the salesman.  Oh.  Bela looks back at anxious Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who are you?  What do you want?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want anything.  I'm just a really big, big fan.  I've seen all your movies.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha! Bela strides out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bela hurries along.  Ed chases after him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why were you buying a coffin?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm planning on dying soon.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (concerned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes.  I'm embarking on another bus- andГіtruck tour of "Dracula." Twelve cities in ten days, if that's conceivable. Bela pulls out a large smelly cigar and lights it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, I saw you perform "Dracula."  In Poughkeepsie, in 1938.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, that was a terrible production. Renfield was a drunk!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought it was great.  You were much scarier in real life than you were in the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I waited to get your autograph, but you never came outside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I apologize.  When I play Dracula, I put myself into a trance.  It takes me much time to re-emerge. A CITY BUS approaches.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, there's my bus. (he checks his pockets)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shit, where's my transfer?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you bave a car?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I refuse to drive in this country. Too many madmen. The bus pulls up, and the doors open.  Ed is worried he's to lose his new friend.  He gets an idea...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed drives anxiously.  Bela sits next to him, filling the with smoke from his big cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, Mr. Lugosi, you must lead such an exciting life.  When is your next picture coming out?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no next picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, you gotta be jokin'!  A great man like you... I'll bet you have dozens of 'em lined up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Back in the old days, yes.  But now -- no one give two fucks for Bela. Bela puffs on his oversized cigar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're a big star!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No more.  I haven't worked in four years.  This town, it chews you up, then spits you out.  I'm just an ex-bogeyman. (he points)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Make a right.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed drives past pumping oil wells and into a seedy neighbo They reach a tiny, well-manicured house.  Ed and Bela get

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (bitter)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They don't want the classic horror films anymore.  Today, it's all giant bugs, giant spiders, giant grasshoppers -- who would believe such nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The old ones were much spookier. They had castles, full moons...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They were mythic.  They had a poetry to them. (he lowers his voice)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you know what else?  The women prefer the traditional monsters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The women?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The pure horror, it both repels and attracts them.  Because in their collective unconsciousness, they have the agony of childbirth.  The blood. The blood is horror.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I never thought of that.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Take my word for it.  You want to "score" with a young lady, you take her to see "Dracula." Bela's eyes twinkle.  He reaches his front door and unloc INSIDE... it's awful.  Squalid, dark, with skulls and str voodoo objects scattered about.  Up front hangs a large photograph of shockingly young Bela, handsome and regal. Ed is stunned by this dismal place, but doesn't say anyth Within, DOGS start BARKING crazily.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh, what a mess. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My wife of twenty years left me last month.  I'm not much of a housekeeper. The dogs BARK louder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh!  I'm coming!  I will feed you!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I guess I should go.  Perhaps we could get together again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he shakes his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly.  But now the children of the night are calling me. Bela smiles and steps inside.  The door closes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores is in her 1950's kitchenette, making a green jell mold.  Ed bursts in, euphoric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sweetie, you won't believe it!  I've got the most incredible news!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (excited)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You got the job?!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?! (confused)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, uh, no, I didn't get the job. But something better happened!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Better than not getting a job?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!  I met a movie star!  Somebody really big!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who?  Robert Taylor?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  A horror movie star!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boris Karloff!?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close!  The other one!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You met Basil Rathbone!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, the hell with you.  I met BELA

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought he was dead. Ed's eyes pop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  He's very alive.  Well... sort of.  He's old, and frail -- but he's still Bela Lugosi!  And he's really nice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boy, I can't even remember the last time he was in a picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a shame.  He's such a rest actor, and nobody uses him anymore.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So did you get his autograph? Ed calms down.  He smiles beatifically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  It wasn't like that at all.  It was just the two of us, and we were talkin'... and he treated me like -- a friend...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed is back in the plant department, arguing with his boss

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's a bum.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No he's not!  Do you realize how much money he made for this studio over the years?  "Dracula"!  "The Raven"! "The Black Cat"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Well now he's a junkie.  He don't deserve to work.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not true --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's so great, you hire him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, uh, if I could I would... The guy takes a mocking face and struts out.  Ed glares.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Halloween night.  CHILDREN in trick-or-treating cost parade up and down the streets.  Through Bela's window, w him and Ed watching TELEVISION -- a small fuzzy screen in huge console.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: ON THE TV, one of Bela's old '30s horror films plays.  Be evil character is hypnotizing somebody: His eyes stare th famous stare, then his hand does the famous hypnotic gest

dialogues.speaker: ON ED AND BELA
dialogues.text: They are entranced.  The men drink beers in silence.  Bel TWO DOGS lie at his feet.

dialogues.speaker: ON THE TV
dialogues.text: The old movie suddenly stops, and VAMPIRA appears on the screen. Vampira, 25, is the sexy "Creature Feature" hoste a pale ghoul slipped into a tight black dress. She leers in front of a corny fog-shrouded set.  There is pumpkin, a broomstick, and a sign reading "Happy Hallowee VAMPIRA (on TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ooo!  Those eyes!  He gives me the willies!  The only thing scarier than him is this guy I dated last week: Charlie from Pittsburgh.  Boy, talk about the living dead...

dialogues.speaker: ON THE MEN
dialogues.text: Ed is disgruntled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh!  I hate the way she interrupts the pictures.  She doesn't show 'em the proper respect.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (glued to the TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think she's a honey.  Look at those jugs. Ed LAUGHS.  Bela waves his arm and starts doing his hypno hand gesture at the TV.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vampira!  You will come under my spell!  You will be my slave of love.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (fascinated by Bela's hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey Bela, how do you do that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You must be double-jointed, and you must be Hungarian. (back at the TV)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vampira, look at me!  Stare into my eyes. Ed joins Bela in this activity.  The two of them wave the arms spookily at the TV. Bela becomes fatigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am getting tired.  I need to take my medicine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you want me to get it for you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No thank you, Eddie.  I'll be alright. Bela smiles.  He gets up, shuffles across the room, and s behind a curtain.  Ed is puzzled.  Bela's thin arm appear draws the curtain tight.  We hear mysterious CLANGING, dr opening and closing, and then silence. Ed sits, waiting. Behind the curtain, something DROPS.  We hear a muffled " Ed is getting worried.  But then the curtain whips open, Bela bounds out, grinning.  He's a bundle of energy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I feel better now.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE DOOR
dialogues.text: The doorbell RINGS.  Kids SHOUT "Trick or treat!"  Bela j up gleefully.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Children!  I love children. Bela puts on his famous cape, then gets a pair of fangs a sticks them in his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: OUTSIDE
dialogues.text: Little kids in Lone Ranger and Howdy Doody costumes giggl expectantly. Suddenly the door flies open, and standing there is Count Dracula!  The real Count Dracula.  YEOWWWW!!!  The kids S and run. Bela chuckles.  Every kid is gone... except one TOUGH BOY

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aren't you scared, little boy?  I'm going to drink your blood!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ehh, you're not a real vampire. You can't turn into a bat, and those teeth don't frighten me. Suddenly Ed lurches out, menacingly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well how about these teeth?!! Ed RIPS HIS TEETH out of his head and thrusts them at the kid.  The boy SCREAMS in terror and races away. Bela is wowed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, how'd you do that? Ed smiles impishly, then sticks the teeth back in his mou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dentures.  I lost my pearlies in the war.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Bela run toward us, Bela's cape flapping in the wi Ed takes a swig from Bela's flask.  They're a bit tipsy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you sure this is okay?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  I do it every Halloween.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The moonlight shines down on a rickety old cemetery.  The blows hauntingly, and tombstones gleam in the blackness. Ed and Bela reach the locked gates.  They glance at each then start to climb over.  Ed helps Bela.  They jump down Ed peers nervously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now what? Bela looks like a child on Christmas morning.  He takes a swig, then starts running giddily. He disappears into the cemetery.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am DRACULA! Bela darts happily through the graves. His cape flies behind him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am the BAT!! Ed's eyes light up.  He starts chasing after Bela. Bela's heart is racing.  He zig-zags past ancient crypts. Gargoyles peer down.  The wind howls through the skeletal trees, silhouetted against the cloudy sky. Ed runs through the shadows, trying to catch up. Bela flaps his cape up and down.  We almost think he's go fly. Ed races up, then quietly stops.  He eagerly watches Bela practically expecting him to turn into a bat.  It's a mag crazed moment.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am DRACUlA!  I will LIVE FOREVER!!! Bela laughs, then lies down on the grass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed slowly walks over and lies next to Bela.  They're happ eyes alert, on top of the world. Ed peers in wonder at his new friend.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed sits across from Georgie.  Ed's very excited.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's the big news you couldn't tell me over the phone... again? Ed gulps excitedly.  He has a spiel all planned out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Weiss, I was thinkin' about what you said, about how all your movies have to make a profit.  And I realized, what's the one thing, that if you put in a movie, it'll be successful??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  Better than tits -- a star! Georgie shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, you must have me confused with David Selznick.  I don't make major motion pictures.  I make crap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, but if you took that crap and put a star in it, you'd have something!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  Crap with a star.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (impassioned)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  It would be something better! Something impressive.  The biggest moneymaker you've ever had!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, maybe you're right.  But it doesn't friggin' matter.  I can't afford a star, so I don't even know what we're talking about. Ed grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What if I told you you could have a star for $1000??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (skeptical)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who? Ed opens his valise and whips out an 8x10 GLOSSY OF BELA.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lugosi?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!  Lugosi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Isn't he dead?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (annoyed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, he's not dead!  He lives in Baldwin Hills.  I met him recently, and he wants to be in our picture.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OUR picture?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sheepishly)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, yeah.  Our picture. Georgie mulls this over.  He's interested.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would Lugosi want to be in a sex-change flick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because he's my friend. Georgie stares carefully at Ed, then finally smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Alright, fine!  You can direct it. I want a script in three days, and we start shooting a week from Monday.

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: He leaps up euphorically.  He eagerly pumps Georgie's han

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thank you!  Bless you, Mr. Weiss! I promise I won't let you down!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: CU on a ROYAL TYPEWRITER.  Ed's hands whirl across the po typewriter, frantically feeding in pages as fast as be ca type.  We PULL OUT. Ed sits on the bed, typing.  He's a blur of activity, jug a cigarette, coffee, and a telephone, while he writes. ED (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Bunny, you're perfect for this job!  You're so good at organizing. His adrenalin is pumping.  Ed pours some booze into his c

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know these people.  I need all the transsexuals and transvestites you can get. (he sucks on his cigarette)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I don't care if they're not actors.  I want realism.  I want this film to tell the truth!  I've waited my whole life for this shot, and I'm not gonna blow it. There's a KNOCK at the door.  Ed carries the phone on a l cord and answers it.  Bela hurries in, smiling broadly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, you got a new movie for me?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, it's gonna be a great picture! You'll love your character! (back into the phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunny, Bela's here.  Look, hit the bars, work some parties, and get me transvestites!  I need transvestites! Ed hangs up and resumes typing.  Bela is puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, what kind of movie is this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, It's about how people have two personalities.  The side they show to the world, and then the secret person they hide inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (delighted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, like Jekyll and Hyde!  Ah, I've always wanted to play Jekyll and Hyde!  I'm looking forward to this production. Ed stops typing.  He pours Bela a drink.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ehh, your part's a little different. You're like the God that looks down on all the characters, and oversees everything.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't understand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... you control everyone's fate. You're like the puppetmaster.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (getting it)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah, so I pull the strings!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.  You pull the strings -- (he suddenly gets a look)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Pull the strings"... hey, that's pretty good! Ed quickly starts typing again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Dolores sit at a card table, finishing up dinner. dogs eat scraps below them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wipe off your hands.  I've got a little surprise for you... (he smiles nervously)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I finished my script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed anxiously pulls out a pile of pages.  Dolores looks in at the cover: "'GLEN OR GLENDA' By Edward D. Wood, Jr""

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, I'm so proud!  I'll read it as soon as I get home.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (apprehensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'd really like to know what you think.  Why don't you go in the bedroom and take a look at it?  I'll Wait... There's an uneasy moment between them.  She senses someth funny.  Dolores takes the script and goes into the bedroo The door closes.  Ed starts pacing...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores reads the script.  She finishes the last page, th looks up.  She is very shaken.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores stands.  She grabs the door and opens it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed stands somberly in drag.  He's in a pantsuit, heels, a pink angora sweater.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores is totally rattled.  She struggles for a response

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So that's where my sweater's been.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed silently nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long have you been doing this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Since I was a kid.  My mom wanted a girl, so she used to dress me in girlie clothing.  It just kinda became a habit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus Christ!  And you never told me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is my way of telling you --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (furious)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What, by putting it in a fuckin' script, for everyone to see?!  What kind of sick mind would operate like that? Ed is terribly hurt.  Dolores shakes tht script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what about this so-called "Barbara" character?  It's obviously ME!  I'm so embarrassed!  This is our life!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (quiet)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course it is.  And that's why you should play the part.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh!  You got nerve, buddy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He calmly points at the script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's a damn good role.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not the issue!! (she suddenly stops)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ugh!  How can you act so casual, when you're dressed like that?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It takes me comfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, just like in the script! Ed smiles serenely.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly. (he takes her hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what do ya say?  Do you wanna break up... or do you wanna do the movie with me? Dolores sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hallway is filled with eager TRANSVESTITES.  It's a v festive atmosphere, and Bunny tries to create some order. Inside the busy office, Paul types, and Conrad cranks a mimeograph machine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's good to have a job.  Now I can get my phone reconnected. In a corner, Georgie angrily waves the script at Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I thought this was gonna be a sex- change film!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (defensive)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's still a sex-change --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah!  Five pages right before it ends!  The rest of the show is about some schmuck who likes angora sweaters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he's a schmuck.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And what's with this new title?!  My poster says "I CHANGED MY SEX"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So change the poster.  Trust me, you'll be better off.  This is a story that's gonna grab people. (he goes into a pitch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's about this guy.  He's crazy about this girl but he likes to wear dresses.  Should he tell her? Should he not tell her?  He's torn. George, this is DRAMA. Georgie throws up his hands

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine, shoot whatever baloney you want!  I give up.  Just make sure it's seven reels long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We are on location for Ed's first film!  A SMALL CREW of dozen unpacks the camera and reflectors from their cars. voice rises above the hubbub.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, could I have everyone's attention?!  Could you gather around? I've got something to say. The crew members put down their things and gather in a ci In the middle, we reveal Ed, in complete drag.  Dress, ny pumps, lovely blonde wig... he's quite a sight.  Like an Scoutmaster, he addresses his troops.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody, we're about to embark on quite a journey.  Four days of hard work... but when it's over, we'll have a picture that'll entertain, enlighten, and maybe even move millions of people. A COUPLE GRIPS glance at each other.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now the only way we're gonna achieve all this is if we stay on schedule. Day one -- TODAY -- we'll start easy. We have eighteen silent scenes that can be shot quickly: Cars parking, Patrick's suicide, me strolling as a man, me strolling as a woman, etc. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: After lunch, we'll bring in the Inspector and the Doctor.  The Doctor is very important to the plot, so we might have to spend time on retakes. But it's worth it.  Scene totals for the first day is thirty-four. (he catches a breath)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Day Two, we'll be a little busier -- Veteran CAMERAMAN BILL, an old guy with thick glasses, sp

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me Eddie, I don't mean to interrupt... but I'm gettin' a little worried about those clouds. He points up.  Everybody looks at the sky.  The clouds ar gray. Ed nods in agreement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good thinkin'.  We'll talk about Days Three and Four later.  Now let's get that first shot off!  It's Scene 17, Glenda looking in the window.

dialogues.speaker: THE CREW
dialogues.text: disperses.  Ed quickly runs in his heels over to the burl make-up man, HARRY.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Okay, do I need any touch-up?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm telling ya, eyelashes are the way to go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (irritated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Harry, we've discussed this a million times.  I don't want to look like a girl.  I want to look like myself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (disgruntled)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fine.  Then you look beautiful. Harry humorlessly powders Ed's nose.  Ed turns away and suddenly SHOUTS into a giant megaphone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonchalant)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed chucks the megaphone and runs crazily past the camera behind a building.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And -- ACTION! A pause, and then Ed, in character as Glenda, calm and dignified, steps out and walks down the sidewalk. Ed stops at a store window.  He's totally in shadow. A grip grimaces.  He TURNS ON a light Ed lights up.  He looks in the window, admires a dress on display, then silently walks out of frame. A beat.  Ed SCREAMS.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And, CUT!  PRINT IT!  LET'S MOVE ON!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't you want a second take, for protection?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (exhilarated)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's to protect?  It was perfect! Suddenly a police car turns the corner.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cops!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't have a permit.  RUN! Everyone grabs equipment and takes off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The company is now shooting inside a dinky soundstage.  T are dirty mattresses tacked on the walls.  They prep Bela set: A fishnet-draped armchair in front of a flat.  Ed is perched high in his director's chair, back in men's cloth

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The set doesn't look right!  It looks too... empty.  Clutter it up.  Put a skeleton in the corner.  And what's that thing over there?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well it looks good.  Let's use it! Georgie hurriedly strides over.  He holds the script.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed!  What's with these revised pages?!  A scene in a smelting factory?  A buffalo stampede?? Three-hundred soldiers storming Anzio Beach                          What's going on here?  I can't afford to film this nonsense!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  We're not gonna film any of it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Then how's it gonna get in the picture?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I know a guy in Universal's stock house -- he's giving me the footage for free.  This movie's gonna look like a million bucks. Georgie nods.  Oh, okay.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lugosi has arrived! Ed jumps excitedly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh my God! (he YELLS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lugosi is here!  Now everyone, when he walks on the stage (nobody is listening; so Ed uses his MEGAPHONE)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now everyone, when he walks on the stage, treat him normal.  I know Bela Lugosi is a world-famous star, and you're all a little excited, but we're professionals.  So if you treat him with respect, everything will be alright.

dialogues.speaker: AT THE STAGE DOOR
dialogues.text: The door swings open, and Bela strides in, looking dapper glances at the teensy stage, and his face falls impercept Ed runs up, bounding with enthusiasm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bela! It's so great to see you! (he glances at his watch)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And eight o'clock on the dot.  Right on time!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I am always on time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course!  Well, we got a big day planned for you... First, we're gonna start off a little easy, with you in that armchair over there.  Then, once you're up to speed and cooking, we'll reset and bring out the laboratory equipment --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he leans in and WHISPERS)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, Eddie, do you have my money?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh?!  Oh yeah, of course. Ed and Bela step over to a corner.

dialogues.speaker: ACROSS THE ROOM
dialogues.text: From a distance, Ed pulls a wad of money from his pocket peels off a few bills for Bela.  The crew watches, fascin

dialogues.speaker: LATER
dialogues.text: Bela is seated in the ratty armchair on the set.  Harry d his make-up.  Harry glances at Bela's arm, and it is full TRACK MARKS.  Harry grimaces, but doesn't say anything. Conrad eagerly scurries up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Lugosi, I know you're very busy, but could I have your autograph?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cordial)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. Conrad hands him a scrap of paper.  Bela signs it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know which movie of yours I love, Mr. Lugosi?  "The Invisible Ray." You were great as Karloff's sidekick. Bela's face suddenly hardens.  He snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Sidekick"??  "KARLOFF"?!! Bela insanely RIPS up the autograph.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fuck you!!  Karloff doesn't deserve to smell my shit!  That limey cocksucker can rot in hell, for all I care!!!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed panickedly runs up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happened?!  Jesus, Connie, what did you do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (upset, close to crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nothin'!  I told him he was great.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How dare that asshole bring up Karloff?!!  You think it takes talent to play Frankenstein?!  NO!  It's just make-up and grunting!  GRRR!

dialogues.speaker: GRRR
dialogues.text: Ed is frozen in fear.  He glances across the stage. Georgie is flabbergasted.  He points urgently at his watc Ed nods.  He motions to Conrad: Get out of here.  Conrad away.  Ed leans in to Bela.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're right, Bela.  Now Dracula, that's a part that takes acting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course!  Dracula requires presence.  It's all in the voice, and the eyes, and the hand -- Bela waves his outstretched arm.  Ed tries to calm him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, you seem a little agitated. Do you maybe wanna take a little break, go for a nice walk... and then we'll come back and shoot the scene?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: BULLSHIT!  I am ready now!  Roll the camera!! The crew is baffled.  Ed shrugs at them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, okay... roll camera

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (unsure)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rolling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sound!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Speed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mark.  Scene Thirty-One. The Assistant CLAPS the slate in front of Bela, then runs

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And... action? It's dead quiet.  Nobody knows what's about to happen. WE MOVE IN TO BELA.  And... he suddenly assumes character Like the consumate pro he is.  Bela gets a wicked, sinist leer, then starts intoning threateningly: BELA (as the SPIRIT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Beware.  Beware!  Beware, of the big green dragon that sits on your doorstep.  He eats little boys! Puppy dog tails!  Big fat snails! Beware.  Take care.  Beware!"

dialogues.speaker: ED
dialogues.text: He is blown away.  He quietly mumbles in amazement.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Brilliant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores studies her script, as the crew lights a flimsy k set.  Ed strolls past, nonchalantly removing a ladies' wi earrings.  She stares in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How can you just walk around like that, in front of all these people?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hon', nobody's bothered but you. (he gestures)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look around -- they couldn't care less.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, this isn't the real world! You've surrounded yourself with

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say it a little louder.  I don't think Bela heard you in his trailer. Dolores quiets down.  She feels bad.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores.  I need your help...

dialogues.speaker: FILMING IN PROGRESS
dialogues.text: A scene is being shot, on camera.  Ed (as Glen) and Dolor Barbara) stare into each other's eyes.  He's dressed norm and she wears a fuzzy angora sweater. ED (as GLEN)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "My mind's in a muddle.  I thought I could stop wearing these things. I tried, honestly I tried..." DOLORES (as BARBARA) (tentative)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Glen, I don't fully understand this. But maybe together -- we can work it out." She stands up, dramatically takes off her angora sweater, gives it to Ed. He holds it meaningfully, then smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Music swells... and CUT and PRINT IT! Ed and Dolores hug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: On a MOVIOLA, we see the black-and-white image of Dolores taking off her angora and giving it to Ed. WE PULL OUT.  Ed and Georgie are hunched over, watching t movie.  Ed smiles proudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And we fade out.  "The End." (the film runs out)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think? Georgie peers at his watch.  He shakes his bead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's fifty-seven minutes long.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah?  Whatever.  So did you like it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (like a lecturing teacher)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, what was the one thing I asked you to do?  Make it seven reels long. I've got contracts with my exhibitors.  If it ain't over an hour, they won't play it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gee, I used every frame of film we shot.  Maybe they won't notice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They'll notice. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look, why don't you let me take over from here?  I can do a few tricks: Pad it out with more stock footage, add establishing shots...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Um, I guess --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good.  And one more thing.  I think your "Written, Directed, and Starring Ed Wood" credit is a bad idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why?!  I did all those things!  Hell, I even built the props.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you did a bang-up job, too.  But you don't want other producers to know that's you in drag.  Trust me. It's a career killer. Ed is quite upset.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But I'm proud.  I wrote, directed, and starred in it just like Orson Welles in "Citizen Kane"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah??  Well Orson Welles didn't wear angora sweaters, did he                         Ed is beaten.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's the cast and crew screening!  The eager two-dozen pe are packed into a tiny screening room. The lights dim, and the movie starts.  A LIBRARY MUSIC fa and then: "Bela Lugosi in GLEN OR GLENDA" Everyone APPLAUDS excitedly.  Bela smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Credits continue: "Featuring Daniel Davis and Dolores Ful The audience is audibly baffled.  Bunny BLURTS out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Daniel Who?! Dolores leans in to Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, who is Daniel Davis?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sour)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some weirdo who likes to wear dresses.

dialogues.speaker: LATER IN THE MOVIE
dialogues.text: ON-SCREEN, Dolores looks tenderly at Ed. DOLORES (on screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Glen.  Is it another woman?" Ed as Glen nervously ponders his response. But suddenly -- MUSIC THUNDERS in.  The movie cuts to buf stampeding.  Bela's angry face is superimposed over this. BELA (on screen)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Pull the string!  Pull the string!"

dialogues.speaker: IN THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: People are impressed by this technique.  Bela nods in app

dialogues.speaker: ON-SCREEN
dialogues.text: Out of nowhere, CHEAP JAZZ MUSIC starts, and the movie ab cuts to SLEAZY STAG PARTY-STYLE FOOTAGE!  A bare-chested whips a bound woman!  A woman dominates another tied to a stick!  A brunette violently rips off her dress and does hoochie-coochie dance!

dialogues.speaker: IN THE AUDIENCE
dialogues.text: The crowd is stunned.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't shoot that! Ed looks back at Georgie, who's wearing a big satisfied g

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie, what's with the stag footage??  You said you were cutting in establishing shots!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did.  I established some tits and ass. Ed rolls his eyes.  He turns back to the movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everybody is CELEBRATING, with a raucous party.  People a boozing it up.  BIG BAND MUSIC plays.  Ed dances with Dol Paul smokes a joint.  Conrad falls over a table and break lamp.  Bela dances happily with a cute young REDHEAD.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wasn't I something..?  Did you see how I command the screen?! Ed's giddy buddies stumble over with foaming glasses of b

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, it was superb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A great show!  A little strange... but great -- especially my scenes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just like I always promised.  Now you're among the immortals.  You're movie stars.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he raises his glass)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here's to Ed.  For making us into something. It's a warm moment.  They all CLINK their glasses. Dolores kisses Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're outside a cute little Spanish bungalow house.  Ed a Dolores are moving in.  They lug furniture from a rented

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: From today on, our lives are different!  We'll be swimming laps in the same pool Jean Harlow did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  It's so much money...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who cares?!  We're on a ROLL!  These are the moments in life you're supposed to grab.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Ed, we're not even married.  And you don't have a job.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you do!  And anyway, I've got tons of new scripts.  And now that I have a track record, studios are bound to hire me! She just stares.  Ed shrugs, semi-reassuringly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look on the bright side.  If we miss the rent, what's the worst they can do?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Toss us out on our ass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Exactly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The house is moved in.  Ed's unkempt dogs run about.  Pum Ed sits on the bed typing fiendishly fast while wearing a angora sweater.  A cigarette dangles from his mouth, and bottle of booze lays in his lap.  Bela sits quietly nearb

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How 'bout a western?  People love westerns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, I don't like horses.  Do I have to get on one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eh, forget it.  What else is big? (his face lights up)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Teenagers!  Jailbait pics!  Yeah... You got the juvenile delinquent, his girlfriend from the wrong side of the tracks --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who do I play?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uh, a cop.  NO!  You play the father. He's angry!  He doesn't like seeing his son -- no -- he doesn't like seeing his daughter behave this way!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (cautious, not to offend)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... can't I play the romantic part?  I'm tired of always being the bad guy.  You know, back in Hungary, I played Romeo!  I would like to be the lover again -- me, in a boat, with the girl... Ed considers this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sure.  Romance, that's great!  To engineer your comeback, we're gonna need a whole slate of pictures.  Once "Glen Or Glenda" takes off, we'll slam you into one, then another, then another!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's good.  I could use the money.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But we need to start off with a bang! Something we know the audience will want to see.  Mmm.  What was your biggest hit?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he thinks)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hmm... my biggest hit?  That would probably be "Dracula."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course! Ed crabs a pen and excitedly scrawls out the word "DRACUL Bela frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those bastards at Universal.  I made so much money for them, and now I can't get the time of day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So let's make another "Dracula." Let's make "The Return of Dracula"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We can't.  Those sons-a-bitches control the rights.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They do?  Shoot.  There must be a way to get around that... Ed's mind is working.  He holds out the paper and stares it.  Suddenly, he grins.  He grabs the pen and makes a pe after the "DR."  It now says "DR.ACULA"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ha-ha!  Dr. Acula!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dracula?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No!  Doctor Acula!  You can still wear the cape, have the fangs... but you're a doctor!  Not a count.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!  This is very exciting.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (inspired)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I gotta type this up, while it's still fresh! Ed rips the paper from his typewriter, puts in a blank pa and starts typing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're outside the imposing gates of MGM.  The lion logo i overhead.  Ed drives up in his dirty Nash Rambler convert He wears his nicest suit.  Ed peers nervously at the GUAR

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, I'm here to see Mr. Feldman. The Guard stares suspiciously at Ed.  His filthy car is l oil.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's your name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Edward D. Wood, Junior. The man frowns.  He looks through his files -- then finds parking slip with Ed's name.  He is surprised.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh.  Eh, he's in the Executive Building.  You can park in the reserved section. Ed smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The room is very posh, with fancy paneling and marble flo Ed sits nervously under posters for "GRAND HOTEL" and "QU VADIS."  Film cans labled "Glen Or Glenda" rest in his la

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Sir, Mr. Feldman will see you now. She hits an electric button.  A large oak door swings ope

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Behind a giant desk is MR. FELDMAN, a glib, thin over- caffeinated man.  He jumps up, smiling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Ward, it's a delight to meet you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his hand)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's Wood.  Ed Wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wood?  Ward?  Wood. (puzzled, he glances at his appointment book)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, what do you know.  It is Wood. Dang secretaries, you can never get a good one.  Right? Ed shrugs.  Feldman grins.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what are you bringing me?  Looks like you got some film cans.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Feldman, some people have resumes to show.  I've got my own movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?!  Well good for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just made this picture, over at Screen Classics.  It opens next week.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screen Classics?  Hmm, don't know them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody in town has seen it, so I'm givin' you first crack at my talents.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't wait to take a look. (he claps his hands)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So what's up next? Ed leans in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Mr. Feldman, I don't believe in thinking small.  So I've got a whole slate of pictures for you: "The Vampire's Tomb," "The Ghoul Goes West"... and "Doctor Acula"!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Doctor Acula?  I don't get it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dr. Acula! Ed writes it out, "DR. ACULA," then waves it in Feldman's Feldman nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, "Dr. Acula."  I get it. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Bela Lugosi's in it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lugosi's washed-up.  What else you got? Ed grimaces.  Lugosi was 90% of his pitch.  He vamps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well... I've got another project I wasn't gonna tell you about. Lugosi's in it, but he's got a smaller part.  The lead is an ingenue, a sterling young actress named Dolores Fuller.  The title is "Bride Of The Atom."

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ah!  Atomic Age stuff, huh?  I like it. (he smiles)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll tell you what, Mr. Ward.  Why don't you leave those film cans, and my associates and I will take a look at your little opus.  Maybe we can do business together. Ed is elated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Feldman and his fellow SMARMY EXECUTIVES sit in a plush screening room.  They are viewing "Glen Or Glenda." ON-SCREEN, Ed is in drag.  A SOLEMN NARRATOR within the m speaks:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Give this man satin undies, a dress, and a sweater... and he's the happiest man in the world.  He can work better, think better, even play better -- and be more of a credit to his community and his government."

dialogues.speaker: THE EXECUTIVES
dialogues.text: They are stupefied.  Yikes!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the hell is this?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this an actual movie?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It can't be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's fuckin' ridiculous! Feldman squints at the screen.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wait a minute.  That guy in the dress -- he's the one I met with today! This must be a big PUT-ON! (he CHUCKLES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's probably another one of Billy Wellman's practical jokes! Everybody suddenly starts HOWLING with laughter.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed zooms up and chipperly jumps from his car.  He buys a Angeles Herald-Express," eagerly opens it to the entertai pages... and then gets a confused look.  Ed quickly start rifling through the pages -- something is wrong.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed angrily shouts into the phone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Georgie, what happened?!  I thought "Glen Or Glenda" was opening next week!  Where's the ads? An OLD-FASHIONED SPLIT SCREEN of Georgie on the phone app

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (pissed-off)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Where's the ads"?!  The ads are in Alabama, Indiana, and Missouri!  You schmuck, it ain't gonna play L.A.!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not??

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I can't sell it to save my life!  You made a goddamn feathered fish.  Is it an art film, a horror show, a hygiene flick?  Nobody knows! I'm beggin' people to book it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (insulted)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe it needs special handling.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Screw you, Wood!  I even sunk more money into different titles: "Transvestite" "He Or She?" "I Led Two Lives"... It DOESN'T MATTER! Nobody wants to see the piece of shit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You can't talk that way about my movie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: "Your movie"?!  I wish it was your movie!  I wish I hadn't blown every dime I ever made into this stinkbomb. If I ever see you again, I'll kill you!!! Georgie SLAMS down the phone.  His split screen WIPES off leaving Ed standing alone. Ed stares at the phone, then quietly hangs it up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WHAM!  A WRESTLER throws another WRESTLER at the mat.  Th crowd CHEERS raucously.  We're at the Saturday Night Wres Matches! In the stands are Ed, Dolores, Bunny, and Bunny's new YOU MALE "FRIEND."  Seated around them are hollering truckers ex-Marines.  Bunny giggles and nudges gloomy Ed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So guess where I'm going next weekend?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know.  Where?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mexico!  And guess what I'm going to do there?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (not enjoying this game)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I dunno.  Lie on the beach?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: WRONG!  I'm getting my first series of hormone shots!  And once those babies kick in, they're gonna remove my organs, and MAKE ME A WOMAN! Ed is astonished.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Jesus!  Are you serious?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes!  I've dreamed of it for years, but your movie made me realize I've got to take action.  GOODBYE, PENIS! The truckers nearby stare.  Dolores covers her face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh!  Will you keep it down? The crowd suddenly ROARS and jumps up.  A favorite wrestl entered the ring, massive TOR JOHNSON, 50.  Tor is an incredible sight: A bald, lumbering behemoth. RING ANNOUNCER (amplified)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now entering the ring, in the gold trunks, 350 bone-crunching pounds of pure strength, the "Swedish Angel"... Tor Johnson!!! The crowd goes apeshit.  The stands are going to collapse the SHOUTING. Ed's eyes are the size of saucers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My God, look at that guy.  He's a mountain! The bell RINGS.  Tor quickly grabs his OPPONENT, a man in blue mask, and throws him at the ground.  Then Tor jumps his stomach, easily picks him up, and heaves him at the r People CHEER.  Ed is flabbergasted.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've never seen anything like him!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And once I'm a woman, Jean-Claude and I are getting married --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (eyes glued to the ring)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ssh!  He's so big!  He's a monster! Can you imagine what that guy would be like in a movie?

dialogues.speaker: ON TOR
dialogues.text: He screams maniacally in Swedish.  Tor lifts the Opponent his head and tosses him into the stands.  Three rows of c get knocked over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tiny miniature European car pulls up.  Tor Johnson is squeezed inside -- ludicrously oversized for this vehicle carefully wedges himself out and enters the bar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This rowdy bar is packed with burly WRESTLERS.  Tor walks and men cheerily yell out: "Hey, Tor!" "Hi, Tor!"  Tor gr In person, he actually seems a jolly, outgoing fellow. Ed waves from the corner

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Johnson, over here! Tor smiles and lumbers over

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Glad you could fit me in your schedule.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (in a hoarse SWEDISH ACCENT)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Da pleasure be mine. They shake hands.  Ed's hands look like a baby's in Tor's mitts. Tor tries to sit in the booth.  But he can't fit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could we moovf to table?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, of course! Ed jumps up.  They move to a large table.  Now Tor is hap He starts shoveling beer nuts into his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So, Mr. Johnson --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tor!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tor.  Have you ever thought about becoming an actor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he CHUCKLES)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mm, not good-lookink enough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think you're quite handsome.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No.  With hair, yah.  But I must shave head for wrestlink.  It scare da crowds.  Dey like that. Ed smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I think you'd be a sensation in pictures.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But what bout accent?  Some people tink I haf too much accent.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah, that doesn't matter!  It's a visual medium. A WAITRESS saunters over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tor, what can I get ya?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll haf eight beers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (nonchalant, to Ed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Uhh, I'll have just one. She walks off.  Tor shakes the now-empty nut bowl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And more nuts! Ed tries to grab Tor's attention.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So anyway, I've got this new script, "Bride Of The Atom," and there's a part you're ideal for: "Lobo."  He's tough.  A brute.  But he has a heart -- and at the end he saves the girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (he laughs merrily)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I like.  When do movie shoot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hopefully, very soon.  I'm just awaiting the final okay from Mr. Feldman at MGM.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed and Dolores are asleep.  Suddenly the phone RINGS.  Ed fumbles for it and groggily answers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wood Productions... We hear Bela's weak VOICE. BELA (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie... help me...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bela? BELA (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie... please come over -- CLICK.  The phone hangs up.  Ed is very alarmed.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The wind is blowing.  Ed's Nash roars up, and he jumps ou coat over his pajamas.  He runs up and POUNDS on Bela's d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bela?! Ed tries the door. It's unlocked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed steps into the dark room, and is stunned by what he se Bela is slumped on the floor, pasty white, eyes glazed. rubber tube is tied on his arm, and a HYPODERMIC NEEDLE l next to him. The dogs crouch behind him, whimpering, despondent, Bela looks up through half-opened eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie... my friend. Aghast, Ed runs over.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bela, what happened?!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't feel well...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me take you to the hospital.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No hospital.  Just take me to the couch... Ed nods.  He picks up the old man and carries him across room to the couch.  The large portrait of Bela, young and robust, peers down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should I call a doctor?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nah.  This happens all the time... Ed puts a pillow under Bela's head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is there anything I can get you? Water?  A blanket?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Goulash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (distressed)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know how to make goulash. Ed sits next to him.  An awkward pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in the needle?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morphine, with a demerol chaser. (he starts crying)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eddie, I'm so broke.  I don't know what I'm gonna do...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't worry.  I'll do something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed stands outside MGM, talking into a phone at the guard ED (on phone)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mr. Feldman!  I haven't been able to get through, so I just showed up. Yeah, out front!  So, are we gonna be working together? (his face slowly falls)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really?  Worst film you ever saw...? (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, my next one will be better. (beat)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dolores tries to cheer up gloomy Ed.  He's wearing angora

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm no good.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ed, it's just one man's opinion!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bela needs a job... I can't even get a film going... (listless)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But of course I can't -- I made the worst movie of all time.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's ridiculous. Ed sighs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All I wanna do is tell stories.  The things I find interesting...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well maybe you're not studio kind of material.  Maybe you just need to raise the money yourself. Ed looks up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
